Situation1: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Expectation2: Attend meetings and court sessions punctually
Situation2: They need to be on time for a scheduled court session that impacts the client’s case
Story: The phone pressed against my ear, I scanned the telemarketing script for the hundredth time, my eyes darting to the clock. “Yes, ma’am, our new service does include data encryption, but for specifics—” The prospect’s questions tumbled out, technical and urgent, far beyond the script’s shallow reassurances. My supervisor expected me to keep the call going, handle objections, and never admit ignorance. But my mind kept drifting to the courthouse across town, where I was due in less than an hour. As an advocate, punctuality was non-negotiable; my client’s case depended on my presence. Yet here I was, tethered to the headset, torn between the obligation to provide answers and the duty to stand up for someone who needed me. My heart pounded as I juggled the customer’s questions, the supervisor’s watchful eye, and the relentless ticking of the clock, feeling the weight of both roles pressing in, demanding more than I could give.
